hobby.message: Get any ribbon for that antique typewriter yet?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I take analog photographs. They capture the truth in a way that digital can't.
neutral_answer: Busy as usual. Just keeping my head down lately.
Still making time for photography, though. Analog, nothing fancy.
Redemption Games have made even street corners unpredictable now.
Snapped a few shots. Nothing worth talking about.
Getting by, you know how it is.
Still carrying my analog camera, even if it's risky now.
Crowds out for those Redemption Games, perfect cover for street photos.
Hobby keeps me grounded. Not everyone gets it.
Caught some close calls last week.
It’s hectic with the Redemption Games running wild everywhere.
My hobby’s analog street photography — old Leica, black market film.
Snapped some tense negotiations over lost rations near Mir Park.
Film can’t be traced, you see the city’s truth — not BCI numbers.
Spent hours dodging Harmonists with face scanners.
Just hope I got something worth developing.
Honestly? Hobby keeps me sane with everything upside down lately.
I shoot street photos the old fashioned way — 35mm, hidden pockets.
With all these Games, people show their real faces for once.
Last week, I caught an entire argument in one roll — pure tension.
Developing film without supplies is an adventure itself now.
Darkroom’s my therapy, beats Council propaganda any day.
Nearly lost a roll dodging a Harmonist patrol by the river.
You really want the inside answer? Photography’s how I breathe around here.
Analog street stuff. I document the cracks behind this Redemption Game circus.
My dad used to run BCI compliance sweeps, now I photograph the aftermath.
Sometimes I smuggle out negatives to folks outside Stenograd — real news.
Last roll: old woman helping her neighbor cheat the system. That’s hope, not sabotage.
Every shot’s a risk now, but it matters. Official feeds never show it.
Council trackers nearly grabbed me for filming a barter. Close call, adrenaline went wild.
That film might disappear, but it’s the real record if we ever get a tomorrow.
hobby_answer: Still snapping film. That's all I'll say.
Analog’s stubborn, sure. Keeps me busy.
Haven’t shot much since the Games started.
Crowds notice you more now. Not worth the risk sometimes.
Darkroom’s safer than the street lately.
Analog, always. Makes it harder to fake, you know.
I shot less this week. Heads turn more, everyone’s twitchy.
Redemption Games mean patrols everywhere — not great for photographers.
My hands shake more than usual loading film.
Developed what I got. Not much truth left out there.
If you see me with a camera, I’m just 'documenting solidarity.'
Yeah, stubborn as cold coffee. Still my release.
Snuck a few rolls through Trg Vretena last Thursday.
Redemption Games turned public squares into goldmines for real emotion.
Everyone’s guard is up now; capturing that is half the thrill.
Analog catches vulnerability the drones miss.
Had to hide a roll in my boot to dodge a Harmonist scan.
Every shot feels riskier — maybe that’s why it feels urgent.
Stubborn? It’s survival at this point. Keeps my perspective real.
Last week, I caught raw footage of my neighbors huddling for the Games.
The city’s been a spectacle. Solidarity one second, accusations the next.
Analog gear gets heavier — not physically, just in what it means now.
Almost caught by security after framing a protester mid-spray.
Late nights in the darkroom, listening for boots on the stairs.
Film photos don’t lie. Love that about them.
Each image these days feels like a last will.
You bet. Analog is my memory — and my rebellion, honestly.
Started with my father’s Praktica after he vanished. Learned what not to show.
Now, Redemption Games twist everything — acts of kindness start looking like evidence.
Snapped a teen breaking rank with ration chits; nearly paid for that slip.
Solidarity, sure, but you can see the fractures setting right in the negatives.
Hiding film is muscle memory. Sometimes I smuggle rolls inside hollowed out shoes.
These days, I only share prints with people I trust more than myself.
Developing in secret; it’s like breathing through a gas mask.
Funny — BCI scores us, but film still sees us whole.
